results.title: Transit: SteamRail workshops
results.creator_credit: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV
results.brief_description:
This episode of ‘Transit’ is the ninth in a series of ten-quarter hour episodes produced by Northern Access Television in 1998.
‘Transit’ was a series of Community TV programs produced about Melbourne’s and Victoria’s Public Transport System and Transport Museum Groups by Michael Costello, a former Melbourne Tram Conductor. Other episodes included episodes on the Bendigo and Ballarat Tramway Museums, the Melbourne Transit Band, the Tramcar Restaurant and many others. In the 1998 series, various members of Northern Access TV assisted in the production of the programs. The programs were all made using volunteers from Northern Access TV on Mini DV cameras.
This episode looks at the SteamRail Workshops, located in the former Newport Railway Workshops. It consists of an interview where David McLauchlan interviews Keith Finlay, secretary of SteamRail Victoria Inc. This non-profit volunteer based association aims to preserve Victoria’s steam powered rail heritage and keep examples of them running for public tours to many destinations on Victoria’s Rail Network. In addition to preserving the days of steam-powered trains, the group also has sections that are dedicated to preserving Diesel and Electric rolling stock as well. During the interview, we see examples of the work undertaken on the carriages and associated equipment.

results.title: Globalisation 101
results.creator_credit: Alex Kelly, Kim Beamish and SKA TV
results.brief_description: Globalisation 101 looks at the impacts of corporate-lead globalisation on workers, indigenous people and the environment both locally and globally. It traces the history of transnational organisations such as the World Bank and International Monetary Fund and charts the origins of third world debt.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alex Kelly, Kim Beamish and SKA TV

results.title: Noise TV - Darebin Music Feast
results.brief_description:
In this episode of Noise TV we join host Shane Laffy, who introduces us to Mayor Vince Fontana for the opening of the Darebin Music Feast, a community celebration inviting and encouraging us to participate in finding expression through the arts, sharing and benefiting from the diverse cultural experiences that enrich our very own continually developing and unique Australian style and identity.
Featuring an original music score by composer Simon Moore with TheNoise performers and performances on this show include, quirky street horn players, Five Angry Men, the infectious dance drum rythms of the Tumbarumba Samba School & Latin Soulfire Dancers, the amazing Soukous Ba Congo,featuring the soulful vocals of King Bell, Kurdish expert instrumentalist Dursam Akar, a tribute concert for pioneer Greek composer Thymios Stathoulopoulos, featuring vocals from mother and daughter Yiota and Maria Stathoulopoulos, and the ever popular sound of Janine Marshall and Neil Robe.

results.title: Painting with light in a dark world
results.brief_description: This is a wonderful documentary containing interviews and observational footage on the life and works of a Kings Cross street photographer, Peter Darren Moyle. Arriving from the bush during the 1980s with no money, no support and no where to live, Moyle with his old 1936 camera in hand, has immortalised the underbelly of Kings Cross with images of prostitutes, drug addicts, transvestites, and the homeless capturing their vulnerability, their loneliness, their pain but also their craziness, their humor, their sense of wickedness. His black and white images can be evocative, confrontational, and even humorous, often mirroring the contrasts of day and night where daytime equals “damaged stock” and night-time equals “alive”. Moyle has had to be resourceful to avoid becoming a victim himself, living in squats, eating out of bins, setting up dark-rooms wherever possible to help finance the special film and developing processes he needs to produce his photographs. He talks about the darker side of his life, his aspirations to be a successful photographer and for his work to be made more available to a wider audience. Through Robert McFarlane, renowned photographer and critic, Moyle is given a chance to come out of the void and into the open - McFarlane wants to set up a solo exhibition of Moyle’s works. This is an uncompromising look at Peter Darren Moyle, his journey as he strives towards his first exhibition, his relationship to the environment and the people he shares his life with but it is also a social commentary of the times we live in. An extraordinary piece of work. Cinematography by Mark Bliss.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 7 [The Big issue. International Women's day]
results.creator_credit: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV
results.brief_description: Et cetera “The Big Issue and International Woman’s Day” is an episode of the general interest magazine program “Et Cetera”. It contains two topics - the first is about the alternative magazine sold on the streets by homeless and unemployed people “The Big Issue”. The second is a look at the celebration of International Woman’s Day, which featrued a rally and march down Swanston Street in Melbourne.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 6 [Joe Felber Multimedia Installation]
results.creator_credit: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV
results.brief_description: Presented by David McLauchlan outside the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art, Melbourne. David interviews multimedia artist Joe Felber and dancer/choreographer Lucy Guerin about their collaborative installation with composer Elliott Gyger entitled “25 songs on 25 lines of 25 words on Art Statement for seven voices and dance” based on Ad Reinhardt’s Black Painting and Art Statement. Following the interviews, there is a presentation of Joe Felber’s 7 minute video on the multimedia performance “25 songs on 25 lines…and dance”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV

results.title: A Kiwi in exile
results.brief_description: Short film made in 1958 by Graham Foster to send to his relatives in New Zealand. Structured as a comic ‘ Day in the life’, the film features footage of Melbourne city and St Kilda and a constant wisecracking narrative from Foster. Of special interest is the segment on Foster’s working day at a Melbourne television station featuring the behind-the-scenes action. As television did not reach New Zealand until 1960, this short film was the easiest way to demonstrate to his family, exactly what he did in Australia.

results.title: Screen sports development workshop
results.creator_credit: Paul Fletcher and Public Programs - Events (Helen Simondson)
results.brief_description:
The SCREENSPORTS event is a unique, entertaining and informative ‘CINEMA EXPERIENCE’. SCREENSPORTS represents an historic leap in the marriage of live performance and technology. It has the potential to be an ACMI flagship pioneering new international standards in screen-based performance. Based on the highly successful Theatre Sports;live improvisation performance the Screensports concept draws on screen culture and the screen as the basis for live improvisation.

A troupe of actors are thrown into virtual worlds utilising the ACMI template sets and the globecaster technology. The actors use these sets as a stimulus for fast and hilarious improvisation.
Screen sports will be fun and informative and appeal to a wide range of people.
In order to develop the Screensports performance it is crucial to conduct a creative development workshop to produce the content for the live performance.

results.title: Melbourne rising
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Sam De Silva and SKA TV
results.brief_description: ‘Melbourne Rising’ is a video document about the S11 protests against the World Economic Forum at Crown Casino in Melbourne. The protests aimed to shut down the summit in opposition to the injustices of corporate driven globalisation. After its release in late September 2000, Melbourne Rising was screened and broadcast in Canada, the Czech Republic, Germany, Italy, the Neteherlands, New Zealand, Switzerland, the UK and the USA. It also featured in numerous film festivals across Australia as well as Korea and India.

results.title: Faces
results.brief_description:
Sue Ford’s experimental film “Faces” consists of portraits of the artist and her friends and acquaintances. Ford filmed each subject for roughly 25 seconds, using a wind-up Bolex camera that framed their faces in close-up. Variously self-conscious, serious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.
